sect1.title: General installation
sect1.para: The &productname; is available at for download as one binary file - a Windows self-extracting ZIP file (.exe extension). There is also an ISO image (.iso) for Windows* 2008 and newer that may be used for VMs running on KVM.

sect2.title: Setup.exe installation instructions for KVM and Xen

step.para: Download the Windows* VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe file directly into your Windows* VM.
Launch the VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe to extract the installation program.
Launch the setup.exe from the root of the newly created directory.
Accept the EULA and follow the prompts to complete the driver installation.
Reboot the VM when prompted by the installation program.

sect2.title: Additional KVM VirtIO setup instructions
sect2.para: Setup.exe can be run with and without VirtIO devices present in the VM. If the devices are present in the VM when setup is run, the drivers are installed and loaded at that time. If the VirtIO devices are not present when setup is run, shut down the VM, add the VirtIO devices, and start the VM. After booting, Windows* will discover the new devices and load the previously installed drivers.

To boot a running VM on a VirtIO disk, the VirtIO disk driver must be installed on a secondary/temporary (e:) VirtIO disk. After the driver is installed and controlling the disk, shut down the VM. From virt-manager, delete the secondary VirtIO disk and delete the IDE boot disk. Now add a disk of type VirtIO or VirtIO SCSI and give it the location for the boot disk. Boot the VM. The VirtIO driver will now be controlling the boot disk.

warning.title: Installation failure
warning.para: Failure to install a VirtIO disk driver on a secondary disk before changing the boot disk to a VirtIO or VirtIO SCSI disk will cause the VM to crash with bug check 0x7b (inaccessible boot disk).

sect2.title: Installation instructions for .vfd and .iso
sect2.para: A Windows* VM may attach the &vmdpa; iso. The ISO contains VirtIO disk drivers for Windows* 2008 and newer. It also contains the full &vmdpa; *.exe file that contains all the VirtIO and Xen drivers for all supported Windows* platforms.

sect2.title: .iso for VirtIO boot disk installation at VM creation
sect2.para: This method is only used for VMs running on KVM and is used to install the VirtIO disk driver on the boot disk while the VM is being installed.

step.para:
See
for attaching an ISO, setting upVirtio Network, and a VirtIO disk for the Windows* VM.
Add the iso to the VM configuration.
Set the boot disk to be of type VirtIO or VirtIO SCSI.
Finish all other VM configuration options.
Start the VM installation.

For Windows 2003, at the very beginning of the installation there is an option to press F6 for an OEM SCSI disk installation. At that time, press F6. The VirtIO disk driver from the vfd can then be selected and installed.
For Windows 2008* and newer, on the Where do you want to install Windows screen, select Load driver and follow the prompts. This will allow the VirtIO disk driver to be installed for the boot disk.
Continue the Windows installation.

After the VM is completely installed, the remaining VirtIO drivers can be installed by copying the VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe from the iso onto the VM's disk and performing a normal VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe installation.

sect2.title: Additional Xen setup instructions
sect2.para: Setup and the /boot_vscsi option: The Xen &vmdpa; SCSI driver is capable of controlling a physical SCSI disk such as /dev/sdb. To run the &vmdpa; SCSI driver on the boot disk, use setup /boot_vscsi. If the /boot_vscsi option is not used with setup, pvctrlw.exe can be used later to indicate that the &vmdpa; SCSI driver should control the boot disk. Before using the /boot_vscsi option or pvctrlw.exe, the VM's configuration file must already contain the necessary SCSI information for the boot disk: the disk line needs to reference the physical disk, for example disk=['phy:/dev/sdb,...'] and there must be a vscsi= line that corresponds to the physical disk. SCSI devices and disks, other than the boot disk, that are to be controlled by the &vmdpa; SCSI driver are not placed in the disk= line but are only referenced in the vscsi= line.

sect2.title: Uninstalling the driver pack
sect2.para: To uninstall the &productname;, execute the uninstall.exe from the \Program Files\vmdp folder. Uninstall.exe will uninstall the &productname; and remove the associated files for the hypervisor that the VM is currently running on. The /virtio and /xen parameters forces the uninstall of those drivers reqardless of the running hypervisor. When uninstalling, it is important to reboot the VM on the currently running hypervisor to all allow the uninstall to clean up additional files and registry entries on reboot.

sect2.title: Upgrading the driver pack
sect2.para: Setup.exe can be used to update most existing installations. To update an existing installation do the following:

step.para: Download the VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe to your Windows VM.
Run VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe to extract the installation program and support files into a subfolder of the folder containing VMDP-WIN-VERSION.exe.
Run Setup.exe from the root of the extracted subfolder and follow the on-screen instructions.
Any Found New Hardware Wizard dialogs that pop up after the update can be ignored or canceled.

sect2.para: With some older installations, setup cannot perform an update. In these cases, setup will inform you that the existing installation will need to be uninstalled first. Uninstall the existing installation. After being completely uninstalled, setup.exe can then be used to install the new files.

sect2.title: Recovering from a failure
sect2.para: If a failure is caused by the driver pack, you can safely remove the driver pack and return to your previous system configuration.

step.para: Shut down the virtual machine and reboot in safe mode.
Uninstall the driver pack (see ).
